Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task feeds directly into the next teammate’s work and delays would ripple.
Situation2: The passenger is heading to a casual meeting with plenty of time
Story: I stared at the clock on my dashboard, my laptop bag wedged awkwardly on the passenger seat. My phone buzzed with a reminder: the report for our team project was due in two hours. I knew if I didn’t finish my section, Priya couldn’t start hers, and the whole team would be set back. But right now, I was behind the wheel, driving a passenger across town. He chatted about his weekend plans, unconcerned with time, his meeting still an hour away. I felt the weight of my colleague’s trust pressing on me—everyone was counting on me to deliver, to keep the workflow moving. But as a taxi driver, I couldn’t rush, couldn’t pull over to type a few lines, couldn’t let my focus slip. My passenger expected a safe, smooth ride, and I owed him that. My mind raced with possible shortcuts, with excuses I could give my team, with guilt at letting either side down. The city lights blurred past as I gripped the wheel, torn between two worlds, each demanding more than I could give.
